code: @Manual{,   title = {{hdrcde}: Highest Density Regions and Conditional Density Estimation},   author = {Rob J Hyndman and Jochen Einbeck and Matthew P Wand},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 3.4},   url = {https://pkg.robjhyndman.com/hdrcde/}, }

what: Highest Density Regions and Conditional Density Estimation
title: Highest Density Regions and Conditional Density Estimation
text: R package hdrcde provides tools computing highest density regions one two dimensions, kernel estimates univariate density functions conditional one covariate, multimodal regression. package implements methods described following papers. Rob J Hyndman (1996) “Computing graphing highest density regions”. American Statistician, 50, 120-126. Rob J Hyndman David Bashtannyk (1996) “Estimating visualizing conditional densities”. Journal Computational Graphical Statistics, 5, 315-336. David Bashtannyk, Rob J Hyndman (2001) “Bandwidth selection kernel conditional density estimation”. Computational Statistics Data Analysis 36(3), 279-298. Rob J Hyndman Qiwei Yao (2002) “Nonparametric estimation symmetry tests conditional density functions”. Journal Nonparametric Statistics, 14(3), 259-278. Einbeck, J., Tutz, G. (2006). “Modelling beyond regression functions: application multimodal regression speed-flow data”. Journal Royal Statistical Society, Series C, 55, 461-475. Richard J Samworth Matthew P Wand (2010) “Asymptotics optimal bandwidth selection highest density region estimation”. Annals Statistics, 38, 1767-1792.

title: Highest Density Regions and Conditional Density Estimation
text: can install stable version R CRAN. can install development version Github
code: install.packages('hdrcde', dependencies = TRUE) # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("robjhyndman/hdrcde")

title: Highest Density Regions and Conditional Density Estimation
text: package free open source software, licensed GPL 3.

title: Box Cox Transformation — BoxCox
text: BoxCox() returns transformation input variable using Box-Cox transformation. InvBoxCox() reverses transformation.

title: Box Cox Transformation — BoxCox
code: BoxCox(x, lambda)

title: Box Cox Transformation — BoxCox
text: x numeric vector time series lambda transformation parameter

title: Box Cox Transformation — BoxCox
text: numeric vector length x.

title: Box Cox Transformation — BoxCox
text: Box-Cox transformation given $$f_\lambda(x) =\frac{x^\lambda - 1}{\lambda}$$ \(\lambda\ne0\). \(\lambda=0\), $$f_0(x) = \log(x).$$

title: Box Cox Transformation — BoxCox
text: Box, G. E. P. Cox, D. R. (1964) analysis transformations. JRSS B 26 211--246.

title: Box Cox Transformation — BoxCox
text: Rob J Hyndman

what: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
title: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
text: Calculates bandwidths kernel conditional density estimates. Methods described Bashtannyk Hyndman (2001) Hyndman Yao (2002).

title: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
code: cde.bandwidths(   x,   y,   deg = 0,   link = "identity",   method = 1,   y.margin,   passes = 2,   ngrid = 8,   min.a = NULL,   ny = 25,   use.sample = FALSE,   GCV = TRUE,   b = NULL,   ... )

title: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
text: x Numerical vector: conditioning variable. y Numerical vector: response variable. deg Degree local polynomial used estimation. link Link function used estimation. Default "identity". possibility "log" recommended degree > 0. method method = 1: Hyndman-Yao algorithm deg>0; Bashtannyk-Hyndman algorithm deg=0; method = 2: Normal reference rules; method = 3: Bashtannyk-Hyndman regression method deg=0; method = 4: Bashtannyk-Hyndman bootstrap method deg=0. y.margin Values y-space conditional density calculated. specified, equi-spaced grid 50 values range y used. passes Number passes Bashtannyk-Hyndman algorithm. ngrid Number values smoothing parameter grid. min.Smallest value consider method=1. ny Number values use y margin y.margin missing. use.sample Used regression method (3) chosen. GCV Generalized cross-validation. Used method=1 deg>0. GCV=FALSE, method=1 deg=0, AIC used instead.  argument ignored deg=0 method>1. b Value b can specified method=1 deg>0. deg=0 method>1, argument ignored. ... arguments control details individual methods.

title: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
text: Window width x direction. b Window width y direction.

title: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
text: Details various algorithms Bashtannyk Hyndman (2001) Hyndman Yao (2002).

title: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
text: Hyndman, R.J., Bashtannyk, D.M. Grunwald, G.K. (1996) "Estimating visualizing conditional densities". Journal Computational Graphical Statistics, 5, 315-336. Bashtannyk, D.M., Hyndman, R.J. (2001) "Bandwidth selection kernel conditional density estimation". Computational statistics data analysis, 36(3), 279-298. Hyndman, R.J. Yao, Q. (2002) "Nonparametric estimation symmetry tests conditional density functions". Journal Nonparametric Statistics, 14(3), 259-278.

title: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Bandwidth calculation for conditional density estimation — cde.bandwidths
code: bands <- cde.bandwidths(faithful$waiting,faithful$eruptions,method=2) plot(cde(faithful$waiting,faithful$eruptions,a=bands$a,b=bands$b))

title: Conditional Density Estimation — cde
text: Calculates kernel conditional density estimate using local polynomial estimation.

title: Conditional Density Estimation — cde
code: cde(   x,   y,   deg = 0,   link = "identity",   a,   b,   mean = NULL,   x.margin,   y.margin,   x.name,   y.name,   use.locfit = FALSE,   fw = TRUE,   rescale = TRUE,   nxmargin = 15,   nymargin = 100,   a.nndefault = 0.3,   ... )

title: Conditional Density Estimation — cde
text: x Numerical vector matrix: conditioning variable(s). y Numerical vector: response variable. deg Degree local polynomial used estimation. link Link function used estimation. Default "identity". possibility "log" recommended degree > 0. Optional bandwidth x direction. b Optional bandwidth y direction. mean Estimated mean y|x. present, adjust conditional density mean. x.margin Values x-space conditional density calculated. specified, equi-spaced grid nxmargin values range x used.  x matrix, x.margin list two numerical vectors. y.margin Values y-space conditional density calculated. specified, equi-spaced grid nymargin values range y used. x.name Optional name x variable used plots. y.name Optional name y variable used plots. use.locfit TRUE, use locfit estimation. Otherwise ksmooth used. locfit used degree>0 link identity dimension x greater 1 even use.locfit=FALSE. fw TRUE (default), use fixed window width estimation. Otherwise nearest neighbourhood estimation used. dimension x greater 1, nearest neighbourhood must used. rescale TRUE (default), rescale conditional densities integrate one. nxmargin Number values used x.margin default. nymargin Number values used y.margin default. .nndefault Default nearest neighbour bandwidth (used fw=FALSE missing.). ... Additional arguments passed locfit.

title: Conditional Density Estimation — cde
text: list following components: x grid x direction density evaluated. Equal x.margin specified. y grid y direction density evaluated. Equal y.margin specified. z value conditional density estimate returned matrix. window width x direction. b window width y direction. x.name Name x variable used plots. y.name Name y variable used plots.

title: Conditional Density Estimation — cde
text: bandwidths omitted, computed using normal reference rules described Bashtannyk Hyndman (2001) Hyndman Yao (2002). Bias adjustment uses method described Hyndman, Bashtannyk Grunwald (1996). deg>1 estimation based local parametric estimator Hyndman Yao (2002).

title: Conditional Density Estimation — cde
text: Hyndman, R.J., Bashtannyk, D.M. Grunwald, G.K. (1996) "Estimating visualizing conditional densities". Journal Computational Graphical Statistics, 5, 315-336. Bashtannyk, D.M., Hyndman, R.J. (2001) "Bandwidth selection kernel conditional density estimation". Computational statistics data analysis, 36(3), 279-298. Hyndman, R.J. Yao, Q. (2002) "Nonparametric estimation symmetry tests conditional density functions". Journal Nonparametric Statistics, 14(3), 259-278.

title: Conditional Density Estimation — cde
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Conditional Density Estimation — cde
code: # Old faithful data faithful.cde <- cde(faithful$waiting, faithful$eruptions,   x.name="Waiting time", y.name="Duration time") plot(faithful.cde)  plot(faithful.cde, plot.fn="hdr")   # Melbourne maximum temperatures with bias adjustment x <- maxtemp[1:3649] y <- maxtemp[2:3650] maxtemp.cde <- cde(x, y,   x.name="Today's max temperature", y.name="Tomorrow's max temperature") # Assume linear mean fit <- lm(y~x) fit.mean <- list(x=6:45,y=fit$coef[1]+fit$coef[2]*(6:45)) maxtemp.cde2 <- cde(x, y, mean=fit.mean,    x.name="Today's max temperature", y.name="Tomorrow's max temperature") plot(maxtemp.cde)

title: Bivariate Highest Density Regions — hdr.2d
text: Calculates plots highest density regions two dimensions, including bivariate HDR boxplot.

title: Bivariate Highest Density Regions — hdr.2d
code: hdr.2d(   x,   y,   prob = c(50, 95, 99),   den = NULL,   kde.package = c("ash", "ks"),   h = NULL,   xextend = 0.15,   yextend = 0.15 )  hdr.boxplot.2d(   x,   y,   prob = c(50, 99),   kde.package = c("ash", "ks"),   h = NULL,   xextend = 0.15,   yextend = 0.15,   xlab = "",   ylab = "",   shadecols = "darkgray",   pointcol = 1,   outside.points = TRUE,   ... )  # S3 method for hdr2d plot(   x,   shaded = TRUE,   show.points = FALSE,   outside.points = FALSE,   pch = 20,   shadecols = gray((length(x$alpha):1)/(length(x$alpha) + 1)),   pointcol = 1,   ... )

title: Bivariate Highest Density Regions — hdr.2d
text: x Numeric vector y Numeric vector length x. prob Probability coverage required HDRs den Bivariate density estimate (list elements x, y z x y grid values z matrix density values). NULL, density estimated. kde.package Package used calculating kernel density estimate den=NULL. h Pair bandwidths passed either ash2 kde. NULL, reasonable default used. Ignored den NULL. xextend Proportion range x. density estimated grid extended xextend beyond range x. yextend Proportion range y. density estimated grid extended yextend beyond range y. xlab Label x-axis. ylab Label y-axis. shadecols Colors shaded regions pointcol Color outliers mode outside.points TRUE, observations lying outside largest HDR shown. ... arguments passed plot. shaded TRUE, HDR contours shown shaded regions. show.points TRUE, observations plotted top HDR contours. pch plotting character used observations.

title: Bivariate Highest Density Regions — hdr.2d
text: information HDRs returned. See code details.

title: Bivariate Highest Density Regions — hdr.2d
text: density estimated using kernel density estimation. Either ash2 kde used calculations. Hyndman's (1996) density quantile algorithm used compute HDRs. hdr.2d returns object class hdr2d containing information needed compute HDR contours. object can plotted using plot.hdr2d. hdr.boxplot.2d produces bivariate HDR boxplot. special case applying plot.hdr2d object computed using hdr.2d.

title: Bivariate Highest Density Regions — hdr.2d
text: Hyndman, R.J. (1996) Computing graphing highest density regions American Statistician, 50, 120-126.

title: Bivariate Highest Density Regions — hdr.2d
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Bivariate Highest Density Regions — hdr.2d
code: x <- c(rnorm(200,0,1),rnorm(200,4,1)) y <- c(rnorm(200,0,1),rnorm(200,4,1)) hdr.boxplot.2d(x,y)   hdrinfo <- hdr.2d(x,y) plot(hdrinfo, pointcol="red", show.points=TRUE, pch=3)

title: Highest Density Region Boxplots — hdr.boxplot
text: Calculates plots univariate highest density regions boxplot.

title: Highest Density Region Boxplots — hdr.boxplot
code: hdr.boxplot(   x,   prob = c(99, 50),   h = hdrbw(BoxCox(x, lambda), mean(prob)),   lambda = 1,   boxlabels = "",   col = gray((9:1)/10),   main = "",   xlab = "",   ylab = "",   pch = 1,   border = 1,   outline = TRUE,   space = 0.25,   ... )

title: Highest Density Region Boxplots — hdr.boxplot
text: x Numeric vector containing data list containing several vectors. prob Probability coverage required HDRs density. h Optional bandwidth calculation density. lambda Box-Cox transformation parameter 0 <= lambda <= 1. boxlabels Label box plotted. col Colours regions box. main Overall title plot. xlab Label x-axis. ylab Label y-axis. pch Plotting character. border Width border box. outline TRUE, outliers drawn. space space box, 0 0.5. ... arguments passed plot.

title: Highest Density Region Boxplots — hdr.boxplot
text: nothing.

title: Highest Density Region Boxplots — hdr.boxplot
text: density estimated using kernel density estimation. Box-Cox transformation used lambda!=1, described Wand, Marron Ruppert (1991). allows density estimate non-zero positive real line. default kernel bandwidth h selected using algorithm Samworth Wand (2010). Hyndman's (1996) density quantile algorithm used calculation.

title: Highest Density Region Boxplots — hdr.boxplot
text: Hyndman, R.J. (1996) Computing graphing highest density regions. American Statistician, 50, 120-126. Samworth, R.J. Wand, M.P. (2010). Asymptotics optimal bandwidth selection highest density region estimation.  Annals Statistics, 38, 1767-1792. Wand, M.P., Marron, J S., Ruppert, D. (1991) Transformations density estimation. Journal American Statistical Association, 86, 343-353.

title: Highest Density Region Boxplots — hdr.boxplot
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Highest Density Region Boxplots — hdr.boxplot
code: # Old faithful eruption duration times hdr.boxplot(faithful$eruptions)   # Simple bimodal example x <- c(rnorm(100,0,1), rnorm(100,5,1)) par(mfrow=c(1,2)) boxplot(x) hdr.boxplot(x)   # Highly skewed example x <- exp(rnorm(100,0,1)) par(mfrow=c(1,2)) boxplot(x) hdr.boxplot(x,lambda=0)

what:
Calculate highest density regions continously over some conditioned
variable. — hdr.cde
title:
Calculate highest density regions continously over some conditioned
variable. — hdr.cde
text: Calculates plots highest density regions conditional density estimate. Uses output cde.

title:
Calculate highest density regions continously over some conditioned
variable. — hdr.cde
code: hdr.cde(   den,   prob = c(50, 95, 99),   plot = TRUE,   plot.modes = TRUE,   mden = rep(1, length(den$x)),   threshold = 0.05,   nn = 1000,   xlim,   ylim,   xlab,   ylab,   border = TRUE,   font = 1,   cex = 1,   ... )

title:
Calculate highest density regions continously over some conditioned
variable. — hdr.cde
text: den Conditional density format output cde. prob Probability coverage level HDRs plot HDRs plotted? FALSE, results returned. plot.modes modes plotted well HDRs? mden Marginal density x direction. small, HDRs plotted. Default uniform HDRs plotted. threshold Threshold margin density. HDRs plotted margin density mden lower value. nn Number points sampled density estimating HDRs. xlim Limits x-axis. ylim Limits y-axis. xlab Label x-axis. ylab Label y-axis. border Show border polygons font Font used plot. cex Size characters. ... arguments passed plotting functions.

title:
Calculate highest density regions continously over some conditioned
variable. — hdr.cde
text: hdr array (,b,c) specifies conditioning value, b gives HDR endpoints c gives probability coverage. modes estimated mode conditional density

title:
Calculate highest density regions continously over some conditioned
variable. — hdr.cde
text: Hyndman, R.J., Bashtannyk, D.M. Grunwald, G.K. (1996) "Estimating visualizing conditional densities". Journal Computational Graphical Statistics, 5, 315-336.

title:
Calculate highest density regions continously over some conditioned
variable. — hdr.cde

title:
Calculate highest density regions continously over some conditioned
variable. — hdr.cde
code: faithful.cde <- cde(faithful$waiting,faithful$eruptions) plot(faithful.cde,xlab="Waiting time",ylab="Duration time",plot.fn="hdr")

what: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
title: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
text: Plots univariate density highest density regions displayed

title: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
code: hdr.den(   x,   prob = c(50, 95, 99),   den,   h = hdrbw(BoxCox(x, lambda), mean(prob)),   lambda = 1,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = "Density",   ylim = NULL,   plot.lines = TRUE,   col = 2:8,   bgcol = "gray",   legend = FALSE,   ... )

title: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
text: x Numeric vector containing data. x missing den must provided, HDR computed given density. prob Probability coverage required HDRs den Density data list components x y. omitted, density estimated x using density. h Optional bandwidth calculation density. lambda Box-Cox transformation parameter 0 <= lambda <= 1. xlab Label x-axis. ylab Label y-axis. ylim Limits y-axis. plot.lines TRUE, show HDRs determined using lines. col Colours regions. bgcol Colours background behind boxes. Default "gray", NULL box drawn. legend TRUE add legend right boxes. ... arguments passed plot.

title: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
text: list three components: hdr endpoints interval HDR mode estimated mode density. falpha value density boundaries HDR.

title: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
text: Either x den must provided. x provided, density estimated using kernel density estimation. Box-Cox transformation used lambda!=1, described Wand, Marron Ruppert (1991). allows density estimate non-zero positive real line. default kernel bandwidth h selected using algorithm Samworth Wand (2010). Hyndman's (1996) density quantile algorithm used calculation.

title: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
text: Hyndman, R.J. (1996) Computing graphing highest density regions. American Statistician, 50, 120-126. Samworth, R.J. Wand, M.P. (2010). Asymptotics optimal bandwidth selection highest density region estimation.  Annals Statistics, 38, 1767-1792. Wand, M.P., Marron, J S., Ruppert, D. (1991) Transformations density estimation. Journal American Statistical Association, 86, 343-353.

title: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Density plot with Highest Density Regions — hdr.den
Highest Density Regions — hdr
text: Calculates highest density regions one dimension

title: Highest Density Regions — hdr
code: hdr(   x = NULL,   prob = c(50, 95, 99),   den = NULL,   h = hdrbw(BoxCox(x, lambda), mean(prob)),   lambda = 1,   nn = 5000,   all.modes = FALSE )

title: Highest Density Regions — hdr
text: x Numeric vector containing data. x missing den must provided, HDR computed given density. prob Probability coverage required HDRs den Density data list components x y. omitted, density estimated x using density. h Optional bandwidth calculation density. lambda Box-Cox transformation parameter 0 <= lambda <= 1. nn Number random numbers used computing f-alpha quantiles. .modes Return local modes just global mode?

title: Highest Density Regions — hdr
text: list three components: hdr endpoints interval HDR mode estimated mode density. falpha value density boundaries HDR.

title: Highest Density Regions — hdr
text: Either x den must provided. x provided, density estimated using kernel density estimation. Box-Cox transformation used lambda!=1, described Wand, Marron Ruppert (1991). allows density estimate non-zero positive real line. default kernel bandwidth h selected using algorithm Samworth Wand (2010). Hyndman's (1996) density quantile algorithm used calculation.

title: Highest Density Regions — hdr
text: Hyndman, R.J. (1996) Computing graphing highest density regions. American Statistician, 50, 120-126. Samworth, R.J. Wand, M.P. (2010). Asymptotics optimal bandwidth selection highest density region estimation.  Annals Statistics, 38, 1767-1792. Wand, M.P., Marron, J S., Ruppert, D. (1991) Transformations density estimation. Journal American Statistical Association, 86, 343-353.

title: Highest Density Regions — hdr
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Highest Density Region Bandwidth — hdrbw
text: Estimates optimal bandwidth 1-dimensional highest density regions

title: Highest Density Region Bandwidth — hdrbw
code: hdrbw(x, HDRlevel, gridsize = 801, nMChdr = 1e+06, graphProgress = FALSE)

title: Highest Density Region Bandwidth — hdrbw
text: x Numerical vector containing data. HDRlevel HDR-level defined Hyndman (1996). Setting `HDRlevel' equal p (0<p<1) corresponds probability 1-p inclusion highest density region. gridsize number equally spaced points used binned kernel density estimation. nMChdr size Monte Carlo sample used density quantile approximation highest density region, described Hyndman (1996). graphProgress logical flag: `TRUE' plots showing progress bandwidth selection algorithm produced.

title: Highest Density Region Bandwidth — hdrbw
text: numerical vector length 1.

title: Highest Density Region Bandwidth — hdrbw
text: plug-rule bandwidth selection tailored highest density region estimation

title: Highest Density Region Bandwidth — hdrbw
text: Hyndman, R.J. (1996). Computing graphing highest density regions.  American Statistician, 50, 120-126. Samworth, R.J. Wand, M.P. (2010). Asymptotics optimal bandwidth selection highest density region estimation.  Annals Statistics, 38, 1767-1792.

title: Highest Density Region Bandwidth — hdrbw
text: Matt Wand

title: Highest Density Region Bandwidth — hdrbw
code: HDRlevelVal <- 0.55 x <- faithful$eruptions hHDR <- hdrbw(x,HDRlevelVal) HDRhat <- hdr.den(x,prob=100*(1-HDRlevelVal),h=hHDR)

title: HDRs with confidence intervals — hdrconf
text: Calculates Highest Density Regions confidence intervals.

title: HDRs with confidence intervals — hdrconf
code: hdrconf(x, den, prob = 95, conf = 95)

title: HDRs with confidence intervals — hdrconf
text: x Numeric vector containing data. den Density data list components x y. prob Probability coverage HDRs. conf Confidence limits HDR.

title: HDRs with confidence intervals — hdrconf
text: hdrconf returns list containing following components: hdr Highest density regions hdr.lo Highest density regions corresponding lower confidence limit. hdr.hi Highest density regions corresponding upper confidence limit. falpha Values \(f_\alpha\) corresponding HDRs. falpha.ci Values \(f_\alpha\) corresponding lower upper limits.

title: HDRs with confidence intervals — hdrconf
text: Hyndman, R.J. (1996) Computing graphing highest density regions American Statistician, 50, 120-126.

title: HDRs with confidence intervals — hdrconf
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: HDRs with confidence intervals — hdrconf
code: x <- c(rnorm(100,0,1),rnorm(100,4,1)) den <- density(x,bw=hdrbw(x,50)) trueden <- den trueden$y <- 0.5*(exp(-0.5*(den$x*den$x)) + exp(-0.5*(den$x-4)^2))/sqrt(2*pi) sortx <- sort(x)  par(mfcol=c(2,2)) for(conf in c(50,95)) {   m <- hdrconf(sortx,trueden,conf=conf)   plot(m,trueden,main=paste(conf,"% HDR from true density"))   m <- hdrconf(sortx,den,conf=conf)   plot(m,den,main=paste(conf,"% HDR from empirical density\n(n=200)")) }

what: Scatterplot showing bivariate highest density regions — hdrscatterplot
title: Scatterplot showing bivariate highest density regions — hdrscatterplot
text: Produces scatterplot points coloured according bivariate HDRs fall.

title: Scatterplot showing bivariate highest density regions — hdrscatterplot
code: hdrscatterplot(   x,   y,   levels = c(1, 50, 99),   kde.package = c("ash", "ks"),   noutliers = NULL,   label = NULL )

title: Scatterplot showing bivariate highest density regions — hdrscatterplot
text: x Numeric vector matrix 2 columns. y Numeric vector length x. levels Percentage coverage HDRs kde.package Package used calculating kernel density estimate den=NULL. noutliers Number outliers labelled. default, points outside largest HDR labelled. label Label outliers length x y. default, outliers labelled row index point (x, y).

title: Scatterplot showing bivariate highest density regions — hdrscatterplot
text: bivariate density estimated using kernel density estimation. Either ash2 kde used calculations. Hyndman's (1996) density quantile algorithm used compute HDRs. scatterplot (x,y) created points coloured according HDR fall. ggplot object returned.

title: Scatterplot showing bivariate highest density regions — hdrscatterplot
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Scatterplot showing bivariate highest density regions — hdrscatterplot
code: x <- c(rnorm(200, 0, 1), rnorm(200, 4, 1)) y <- c(rnorm(200, 0, 1), rnorm(200, 4, 1)) hdrscatterplot(x, y)  hdrscatterplot(x, y, label = paste0("p", 1:length(x)))

what: Speed-Flow data for Californian Freeway — lane2
title: Speed-Flow data for Californian Freeway — lane2
text: two data sets collected 1993 two individual lanes (lane 2 lane 3) 4-lane Californian freeway -880. data collected loop detectors, time units 30 seconds per observation (see Petty et al., 1996, details).

title: Speed-Flow data for Californian Freeway — lane2
code: lane2; lane3

title: Speed-Flow data for Californian Freeway — lane2
text: Two data frames (lane2 lane3) 1318 observations following two variables: flow numeric vector giving traffic flow vehicles per lane per hour. speed numeric vector giving speed miles per hour.

title: Speed-Flow data for Californian Freeway — lane2
text: Petty, K.F., Noeimi, H., Sanwal, K., Rydzewski, D., Skabardonis, ., Varaiya, P., Al-Deek, H.  (1996). ``Freeway Service Patrol Evaluation Project: Database Support Programs, Accessibility''. Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies, 4, 71-85. data provided courtesy CALIFORNIA PATH, Institute Transportation Studies, University California, Berkeley.

title: Speed-Flow data for Californian Freeway — lane2
text: data examined Einbeck Tutz (2006), using nonparametric approach multi-valued regression based conditional mean shift.

title: Speed-Flow data for Californian Freeway — lane2
text: Einbeck, J., Tutz, G. (2006). ``Modelling beyond regression functions: application multimodal regression speed-flow data''. Journal Royal Statistical Society, Series C (Applied Statistics), 55, 461-475.

title: Speed-Flow data for Californian Freeway — lane2
code: plot(lane2)  plot(lane3)

title: Nonparametric Multimodal Regression — modalreg
text: Nonparametric multi-valued regression based modes conditional density estimates.

title: Nonparametric Multimodal Regression — modalreg
code: modalreg(   x,   y,   xfix = seq(min(x), max(x), l = 50),   a,   b,   deg = 0,   iter = 30,   P = 2,   start = "e",   prun = TRUE,   prun.const = 10,   plot.type = c("p", 1),   labels = c("", "x", "y"),   pch = 20,   ... )

title: Nonparametric Multimodal Regression — modalreg
text: x Numerical vector: conditioning variable. y Numerical vector: response variable. xfix Numerical vector corresponding input values fitted values shall calculated. Optional bandwidth \(x\)-direction. b Optional bandwidth \(y\)-direction. deg Degree local polynomial used estimation (0 1). iter Positive integer giving number mean shift iterations per point branch. P Maximal number branches. start Character determining starting points selected. "q": proportional quantiles; "e": equidistant; "r": random.  , "q", "e", "r", give starting points constant x.  alternative, choice "v" gives variable starting points, equal "q" smallest x, equal previously fitted values subsequent x. prun Boolean. TRUE, parts branches dismissed (plotted output) associated kernel density value falls threshold 1/(prun.const*(max(x)-min(x))*(max(y)-min(y))). prun.const Numerical value giving constant used (higher, less pruning) plot.type Vector two elements. first one character-valued, possible values "p", "l", "n".  equal "n", plotted output given . equal "p", fitted curves symbolized points graphical output, otherwise lines.  second vector component numerical value either 0 1. 1, position starting points depicted plot, otherwise omitted. labels Vector three character strings.  first one "main" title graphical output, second one label \(x\) axis, third one label \(y\) axis. pch Plotting character. default corresponds small bullets. ... arguments passed cde.bandwidths.

title: Nonparametric Multimodal Regression — modalreg
text: list following components: xfix Grid predictor values fitted values calculated. fitted.values [P x length(xfix)]- matrix fitted j-th branch j-th row (\(1 \le j \le P\)) bandwidths vector bandwidths b. density [P x length(xfix)]- matrix estimated kernel densities. computed prun=TRUE. threshold pruning threshold.

title: Nonparametric Multimodal Regression — modalreg
text: Computes multi-modal nonparametric regression curves based maxima conditional density estimates. tool estimation conditional mean shift outlined Einbeck Tutz (2006).  Estimates conditional modes might fluctuate highly deg=1.  Hence, deg=0 recommended. bandwidth selection, hybrid rule introduced Bashtannyk Hyndman (2001) employed deg=0. corresponds setting method=1 function cde.bandwidths. deg=1 automatic bandwidth selection supported.

title: Nonparametric Multimodal Regression — modalreg
text: Einbeck, J., Tutz, G. (2006) "Modelling beyond regression functions: application multimodal regression speed-flow data". Journal Royal Statistical Society, Series C (Applied Statistics), 55, 461-475. Bashtannyk, D.M., Hyndman, R.J. (2001) "Bandwidth selection kernel conditional density estimation". Computational Statistics Data Analysis, 36(3), 279-298.

title: Nonparametric Multimodal Regression — modalreg
text: Jochen Einbeck (2007)

title: Nonparametric Multimodal Regression — modalreg
code: lane2.fit <- modalreg(lane2$flow, lane2$speed, xfix=(1:55)*40, a=100, b=4)  #> 10 ..20 ..30 ..40 ..50 ..

title: Plots conditional densities — plot.cde
text: Produces stacked density plots highest density region plots univariate density conditional one covariate.

title: Plots conditional densities — plot.cde
code: # S3 method for cde plot(   x,   firstvar = 1,   mfrow = n2mfrow(dim(x$z)[firstvar]),   plot.fn = "stacked",   x.name,   margin = NULL,   ... )

title: Plots conditional densities — plot.cde
text: x Output cde. firstvar one conditioning variable, firstvar specifies variable fix first. mfrow one conditioning variable, mfrow passed par plotting. plot.fn Specifies plotting function use: "stacked" results stacked conditional densities "hdr" results highest density regions. x.name Name x (conditioning) variable use x-axis. margin Marginal density conditioning variable. present, conditional densities corresponding non-negligible marginal densities plotted. ... Additional arguments plot.

title: Plots conditional densities — plot.cde
text: plot.fn=="stacked" one conditioning variable, function returns output persp.  plot.fn=="hdr" one conditioning variable, function returns output hdr.cde. one conditioning variable, nothing returned.

title: Plots conditional densities — plot.cde
text: Hyndman, R.J., Bashtannyk, D.M. Grunwald, G.K. (1996) "Estimating visualizing conditional densities". Journal Computational Graphical Statistics, 5, 315-336.

title: Plots conditional densities — plot.cde
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Plots conditional densities — plot.cde
code: faithful.cde <- cde(faithful$waiting,faithful$eruptions,    x.name="Waiting time", y.name="Duration time") plot(faithful.cde)  plot(faithful.cde,plot.fn="hdr")

what: Plot HDRs with confidence intervals — plot.hdrconf
title: Plot HDRs with confidence intervals — plot.hdrconf
text: Plots Highest Density Regions confidence intervals.

title: Plot HDRs with confidence intervals — plot.hdrconf
code: # S3 method for hdrconf plot(x, den, ...)

title: Plot HDRs with confidence intervals — plot.hdrconf
text: x Output hdrconf. den Density data list components x y. ... arguments passed plot.

title: Plot HDRs with confidence intervals — plot.hdrconf
text: None

title: Plot HDRs with confidence intervals — plot.hdrconf
text: Hyndman, R.J. (1996) Computing graphing highest density regions American Statistician, 50, 120-126.

title: Plot HDRs with confidence intervals — plot.hdrconf
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Plot HDRs with confidence intervals — plot.hdrconf
code: x <- c(rnorm(100,0,1),rnorm(100,4,1)) den <- density(x,bw=bw.SJ(x)) trueden <- den trueden$y <- 0.5*(exp(-0.5*(den$x*den$x)) + exp(-0.5*(den$x-4)^2))/sqrt(2*pi) sortx <- sort(x)  par(mfcol=c(2,2)) for(conf in c(50,95)) {   m <- hdrconf(sortx,trueden,conf=conf)   plot(m,trueden,main=paste(conf,"% HDR from true density"))   m <- hdrconf(sortx,den,conf=conf)   plot(m,den,main=paste(conf,"% HDR from empirical density\n(n=200)")) }

title: Version 3.4
text: CRAN release: 2021-01-18 Bug fixes documentation updates Added labels hdrscatterplot (thanks Fan Cheng)

title: Version 3.3
text: CRAN release: 2018-12-21 options hdr.boxplot (thanks Simon Carrignon) flexible hdr.den plots (thanks Simon Carrignon) Fixed colours hdrscatterplot

title: Version 3.2
text: CRAN release: 2018-01-29 Updated hdr.den() demonstrate calculation hdr clearly (thanks Dennis Freuer suggestion) Added hdrscatterplot() function Roxygenized package Added pkgdown site

title: Version 3.1
text: CRAN release: 2013-10-19 Added dependency mvtnorm avoid problems ks.

title: Version 3.0
text: CRAN release: 2013-08-28 Reduced dependency KernSmooth changed ::: calls :: New functions hdr.2d() plot.hdr2d() return plot bivariate HDR information. Rewritten hdr.boxplot.2d() function.

title: Version 2.16
text: CRAN release: 2012-03-30 Replaced .Internal() calls new .filled.contour() function.

title: Version 2.15
text: CRAN release: 2010-11-11 Added option control limits density estimate hdr.boxplot.2d()

title: Version 2.14
text: CRAN release: 2010-04-20 Updated references hdrbw().

title: Version 2.13
text: CRAN release: 2010-01-26
code: * Added color options to hdr.boxplot.2d().

title: Version 2.12
text: CRAN release: 2009-10-13
code: * Modified hdr(), hdr.boxplot() and hdr.den() to allow a Box-Cox transformation to be used when computing the density. This allows the density estimate to be non-zero only on the positive real line.

title: Version 2.11
text: CRAN release: 2009-09-18 Added hdrbw() Matt Wand compute better bandwidths hdr(), hdr.den() hdr.boxplot(). Fixed bugs help files.

title: Version 2.10
text: CRAN release: 2009-08-19 Bug fix hdr.boxplot.2d(). show.points option working.

title: Version 2.09
text: CRAN release: 2008-11-20 Bug fix: bandwidth cde() fw=TRUE use.locfit=TRUE twice large .

title: Version 2.08
text: CRAN release: 2008-10-08
code: * Bug fix in hdr.boxplot.2d(). It would sometimes plot outliers on a separate plot. * New argument to hdr.boxplot.2d() to allow the density to be estimated using the kde() function from the ks package.
